snippet.textDisplay:
This video is about a uniformed thug who betrays the oath that he took in order to get that uniform.

In this incident, he violates 18 USC 241 and 242, “Conspiracy Against Rights” and “Deprivation of Rights under Color of Law.” Specifically, this badged criminal attempts to deprive an innocent passerby of his 1st Amendment right to freedom of speech.

snippet.textDisplay:
A&E... Why are you supporting this criminal in a costume depriving the truck driver of his 1st ammendment rights?? He blatantly lies to the guy he illegally pulls over by telling him that he can't yell what he did out his window in order to threaten him with an unwarranted and also illegal disorderly conduct ticket. He then pretends like he's such an honorable person by only giving him a warning instead of a ticket??? Where is the honor in that?? Why isni't he honoring his oath that he took when he swore to protect the constitution, and therein this guys 1st ammendment right to free speech, when he became a cop. Being a cop does not give him the right to make up laws as he feels so that he can violate that man's constitutional rights.
A&E, you should be ashamed for propalgating this and giving this road pirate a platform in which to rob citizens of their god given rights protected by the constitution of the United States of America. And the people watching this should understand that that is exactly what A&E is doing and you should not be okay with it!!

And the people watching this should understand that that is exactly what A&E is doing and you should not be okay with it!!

snippet.textDisplay: Using offensive language is disrespectful, but it is not a crime, and it is freedom of speech guaranteed by the first amendment. Cops are not Gods with badges of God authority over the populace. Cops are servants of We the People, NOT Masters. All cops should cease biting the hands that feeds you. We the People are your EMPLOYERS, don't you ever forget it, or go live in Russia, or China, or be removed as public servant. You are not serving us, when you act as tyrants with badges!!!!!!!

snippet.textDisplay:
"one man's vulgarity is another's lyric", supreme court in Cohen v California.
We have the right to offensive speech, we have the right to be critical of our government.

This stop is covered under law, 18 USC 242. The criminal has a badge. He has also surrendered qualified immunity against lawsuits, 42 USC 1983.

And that A&E chose to air this, I hope the victim here sues them too.

snippet.textDisplay: What happened to the 1st Amendment Freedom of Speech where this occurred?  So many courts including SCOTUS has ruled on this very subject.   "Don't be swearing at the cops"???  That is protected free speech!  How can anti-profanity laws be considered constitutional in the wake of the U.S. Supreme Court’s famous decision in Cohen v. California (1971)?  Justice John Marshall Harlan II began his opinion with these words: “This case may seem at first blush too inconsequential to find its way into our books, but the issue it presents is of no small constitutional significance.” He also famously wrote that “one man’s vulgarity is another's lyric” and warned that government officials might ban particular four-letter words as a way to silence particular viewpoints. "Justice Lewis Powell also explained in a concurring opinion in Lewis v. New Orleans (1972) that speech directed to police officers may not rise to the level of fighting words because officers receive special training to be able to deal with obstreperous individuals."  There was no law broken in this instants except for the illegal stop by the sheriff's deputy and subsequent demand for and "check" on his license.
snippet.textOriginal: What happened to the 1st Amendment Freedom of Speech where this occurred?  So many courts including SCOTUS has ruled on this very subject.   "Don't be swearing at the cops"??? Justice John Marshall Harlan II began his opinion with these words: “This case may seem at first blush too inconsequential to find its way into our books, but the issue it presents is of no small constitutional significance.” He also famously wrote that “one man’s vulgarity is another's lyric” and warned that government officials might ban particular four-letter words as a way to silence particular viewpoints. "Justice Lewis Powell also explained in a concurring opinion in Lewis v. New Orleans (1972) that speech directed to police officers may not rise to the level of fighting words because officers receive special training to be able to deal with obstreperous individuals."
